recipeIngredient: 2  boneless pork loin chops (¬Ω-inch thick) ((¬Ω lb, 227 g))

recipeInstructions.text: Over a small bowl, grate ¬º onion (use about half of it) and set aside.

recipeInstructions.text: Shred ¬º head green cabbage into thin slices (I‚Äôm using a Japanese cabbage shredder) and cut 1 tomato into wedges.

recipeInstructions.text: Make the sauce. In a medium bowl, combine 3 Tbsp ponzu, 3 Tbsp sake, and ¬Ω Tbsp soy sauce. Whisk it all together.
recipeInstructions.name: Make the sauce. In a medium bowl, combine 3 Tbsp ponzu, 3 Tbsp sake, and ¬Ω Tbsp soy sauce. Whisk it all together.

recipeInstructions.text: In order to sear the meat perfectly, pat dry 2 boneless pork loin chops (¬Ω-inch thick) with paper towels. Removing the moisture will prevent the meat from steaming.
recipeInstructions.name: In order to sear the meat perfectly, pat dry 2 boneless pork loin chops (¬Ω-inch thick) with paper towels. Removing the moisture will prevent the meat from steaming.

recipeInstructions.text: Make a couple of slits on the connective tissue between the meat and the fat on both sides of the meat. Red meat and fat have different elasticities and will shrink and expand at different rates when cooked. These slits allow the pork loin chops to stay nice and flat while cooking instead of curling up.

itemListElement.text: Heat the frying pan over medium-high heat and add 1 Tbsp neutral oil. When the pan is hot, add the pork loin chops. Cook for 4 minutes on each side. Do not flip until the bottom is nicely golden brown. If you‚Äòre preparing more than 2 pieces, cook them in batches. Give some space between the meat to ensure nice searing and prevent steaming the meat.  Browning the meat gives an important flavor component.¬†The meat should be flat to get evenly golden brown, and that‚Äòs why making slits is important in step 6.

review.reviewBody: This came out so nicely! Left a comment on the Youtube video already, but just wanted to leave a rating here as well.

I wish I took a picture before we gobbled it all up.  I served it with miso soup using Hikari miso, goma ae green beans and gobo, and Japanese potato salad all using your recipes.   I also made a quick cucumber pickle with ume and katsuoboshi.  I have to mention that your goma ae recipe is also a family  favorite.  I made it for my 84 year old aunty and she really enjoyed it.  She cannot do very much these days but I let her grind the sesame seeds. I think that‚Äôs why it tasted extra good to her üòâ.  Thank you for your delicious recipes and your wonderful descriptions.  I will keep referring to your recipes for dinner inspiration!  BTW I love Midnight Diner too.
